submit plans for review by the city planning commission the planning commission shall forward a recommendation of approval or disapproval for expansion to the city council b the opening and development of new sections of a city cemetery shall be approved by council resolution the city council may set apart or reserve lots for the interment of strangers and indigents v 1396 administration a the city manager shall be responsible to the city council for the efficient and proper management and control of all cityowned cemeteries the city manager may delegate the responsibility for immediate supervision of operations maintenance and administration to one or more designated supervisors b the city may contract with a private contractor to operate and maintain the cemetery after obtaining competitive bids the private contractor shall be under the immediate jurisdiction of the city manager or his designate c it shall be the duty of the city manager to advise and make recommendations to the city council for the purpose of improving cemetery management and operation vi 1396 rules and regulations a the city manager may recommend rules and regulations for council adoption whenever in his judgment the best interests and safety of the public and the cemetery would be served b every lot or grave sold is subject to the rules and regulations now in force or that may be hereafter adopted and to such changes of the present rules and regulations as are found necessary for the protection of lot owners and the remains of the dead all rules and regulations currently in effect shall remain in effect until or unless amended by council resolution c any violation of any rule or regulation governing city cemeteries shall be a violation of this article vii 1396 cemetery fees and charges a cemetery fees and charges shall be set by council by resolution b council may set some or all cemetery fees and charges for nonresidents at a higher amount than those for residents c all cemetery fees and charges currently in effect shall remain in effect until or unless amended by council resolution viii 1396 purchase of lots purchases of lots in the cemetery shall be made from the city clerk and the purchasers shall acquire only the privilege of burial rights in the lot so purchased the cost of any lot shall be paid in full at the time of purchase no sale will be made of less than a complete lot according to the cemetery plans ix 1396 certificates of ownership ownership of a lot shall be evidenced by a certificate ownership certificates shall bear the name of the owner lot number number of graves name of cemetery and such other information as may be necessary and shall be signed by the city clerk x 1396 recording power to act power to act for the owner of any lot shall be filed for record with the city clerk to become operative xi 1396 burial designations the lot owner or his legal representative may at any time designate in writing whom he wishes buried in his lot or grave forbid the burial of certain persons and have a record made of such desire with the city clerk xii 1396 transfer of ownership a transfers shall be made upon application only b no transfer shall take place without proof of ownership which shall be evidenced by a certificate which shall be surrendered and a new certificate issued in the event of a transfer c the ownership of any lot shall not be fully effective until the records of the cemetery have been changed to show the new owner d in the absence of a written order to the contrary the city shall after the owners death honor a transfer of ownership by court order when presented for record with the city clerk e in cases where the owner is deceased and there is no estate to be probated the heirs of the deceased may make application for transfer to the city clerk and upon submission of satisfactory evidence approved by the city manager the clerk shall issue a new certificate to the heirs entitled thereto xiii 1396 lost or destroyed certificates in case of loss or destruction of a certificate of ownership no new certificate shall be issued in lieu thereof except upon satisfactory proof to the city manager of such loss or destruction and upon the giving of satisfactory security by bond or otherwise against loss to the city as may be required by the city manager any new such certificate shall be plainly marked duplicate upon its face xiv 1396 perpetual care a perpetual care is the general maintenance and care of burial units in the cemetery 1 the term perpetual care used in reference to burial units shall be held to mean the cutting of grass upon said burial unit at reasonable intervals the raking and cleaning of the burial units at reasonable intervals the pruning of shrubs and trees and maintaining roadways walkways boundaries and maintenance buildings 2 the term perpetual care shall in no case be construed as meaning the maintenance repair or replacement of any grave stones monumental structures or memorials placed or erected on burial units  nor the planting or cost of flowers or ornamental plants  nor sprinkling said burial units with water  nor the maintenance or doing of any special or unusual work in the cemetery such as filling depressions  nor does it mean the reconstruction of any marble granite bronze or concrete work on any burial unit in the cemetery or other buildings or structures made necessary by injuries caused by the elements an act of god common enemy thieves vandals strikers malicious mischief makers explosives unavoidable accidents invasions riots resurrection or by the order of any military or civil authority whether the damage be direct or collateral other than herein provided for b the city of richmond does hereby bind itself as a general obligation of the city for the perpetual care of all existing and future burial plots and mausoleums located in the cemetery c the council resolution adopted  creating the perpetual and annual care fund is hereby rescinded and the perpetual care fund is hereby dissolved all monies in the perpetual care fund collected from the sale of burial plots shall be transferred to the cemetery fund and all monies collected from the sale of burial crypts and cremain niches shall be transferred to the mausoleum fund earned interest shall be transferred in the amounts as a percentage based on the principal amounts transferred to the cemetery fund and the mausoleum fund respectively the money so transferred shall be used for directly related expenses for operation maintenance administration and improvements of the cemetery and mausoleum xv 1396   3104 performance of work the city reserves the right to have all foundations for monuments headstones markers and shall injure or destroy take or carry away any vase flower pot or other container or ornament that may have been placed in the cemetery except such as were originally brought in by the person so any description city vehicles excluded shall be driven or propelled in any cemetery except upon the portions of the roadways set aside for vehicular traffic b no vehicle shall be driven in any cemetery at any time at a speed greater than is reasonable and proper under all circumstances and in no event in excess of 15 miles per hour xx 1396 noise disorderly conduct no person shall make any improper noise or disturbance or conduct himself in a disorderly manner within the limits of any cemetery xxi 1396 refreshments etc no person shall take any refreshment food or intoxicating beverage of any kind within the boundary of any cemetery except such food and temperate beverages as may be required by workers engaged therein xxii 1396 firearms explosives no person shall take any explosives within the boundary of any cemetery and no person shall discharge any firearms or explosives within the boundary of any cemetery unless he or she is a police or peace officer on official duty except that military or other organizations may carry arms therein for the purpose of firing a salute at the chapel burial service of a member of their organization or upon observance of memorial services xxiii 1396 trespassing walking or driving cemetery grounds to property or land outside of any cemetery for the purpose of saving time or distance is strictly prohibited xxiv 1396 rubbish it shall be unlawful for any person to leave or scatter rubbish within the confines of any cemetery xxv 1396 violations any person or customer found guilty of violating any of the provisions of this article shall be deemed guilty of a misdemeanor and upon conviction thereof may be punished by a fine of not more than $50000 for each violation and may be imprisoned in the county jail for a period of up to 90 days in the discretion of the court each day upon which a violation of the provisions of this article shall occur shall be deemed a separate and additional violation for the purpose of this article  in general secs 4214225  reserved article ii  alarm systems definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning alarm system means any mechanical or electrical device which activates emits a sound or transmits a signal or message to which the police may be summoned directly or indirectly to respond an alarm system is designed for use for one or any combination of the following the detection of an unlawful entry or attempted unlawful entry into a building structure or facility and the alerting of others of the commission of an unlawful act within a building structure or facility alarm user means any owner or occupant who has physical control over the premises where an alarm system is installed within the city except for alarm systems on a motor vehicle however if an alarm system on a motor vehicle is connected to an alarm system at a premises the person using andor operating such vehicle is an alarm user excluded from this definition and coverage of this article are persons who use selfcontained alarm systems ie a system which signals or alerts other authorized persons who are on the premises of an attempted unauthorized intrusion or holdup attempt however if such a system employs an audible signal emitting sounds flashing light or beacon designed to signal persons outside the premises such system shall be within the definition of an alarm system and shall be subject to this article false alarm means a bell mechanical electrical or telephone apparatus or combination thereof which is activated for the purpose of summoning the city police department to respond to a holdup breakin burglary unauthorized entry destruction of property or other event requiring police response when in fact the service called for is not needed shall be deemed a false alarm within the meaning of this article twelvemonth period means the period commencing on june 20 and the same date of each following calendar year  52091 cross reference definitions generally  12 payment of fee required for false alarms  amounts set by council resolution to defray the cost of responding to false alarms and to discourage the continuation of repeat false alarms the alarm user shall be assessed a false alarm fee by the city for each false alarm the amount to be charged for each false alarm shall be set by resolution of the city council and may provide that there be no charge for the first and second false alarms within any 12month period  52091 exceptions to false alarm charge each of the following circumstances shall not constitute a false alarm and no fee shall be assessed 1 alarm system malfunctions provided that corrective measures have been instituted within 72 hours after the alarm and notification and proof of such corrective measures is immediately provided to the city police department 2 alarm conditions activated by a person working on the system ie system testing provided that prior notification to the city police department has been given 3 alarms which the alarm user can substantiate as being activated by disruption or disturbance of utility company facilities by a motor vehicle or by storm conditions  and such disruption or disturbance is outside the control of the alarm user  52091 appeal of false alarm charge any alarm user may appeal the charging of a false alarm fee to the city council such appeal shall be in writing and served upon the city clerk within ten calendar days after notification of assessment  52091 penalty for violation of article beginning with the third and any subsequent false alarms in a 12month period the police officer responding to such alarm may issue an appearance ticket to the alarm user in the amount set forth by the city council resolution as provided in section 4227  52091 failure to pay fee for false alarm failure of an alarm user to remit payment of a false alarm fee may at the option of the city result in the commencement of a civil action for collection of the fee  52091 monitoring services a the city council may assess the alarm user a fee to provide monitoring services the amount to be charged for monitoring services shall be set by resolution of the city council b notwithstanding any provision hereof nothing in this section shall be construed as requiring the city to maintain monitoring services or to enter into any agreement to monitor any alarm system monitoring services existing on  may be discontinued upon reasonable notice from the city to the alarm user  52091 environment footnotes  1  cross reference businesses ch 22  community development ch 34  zoning app a state law reference air pollution act mcl 46664670  reserved article iv  nuisances definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning nuisance means any person doing an unlawful act or omitting to perform a duty or suffering or permitting any condition or thing to be or exist which act omission condition or thing either 1 injures or endangers the comfort repose health or safety of others  2 offends decency  3 is offensive to the senses  4 unlawfully interferes with obstructs or tends to obstruct or renders dangerous for passage any public or private street highway sidewalk stream ditch or drainage  5 in any way renders other persons insecure in life or the use of property  or 6 essentially interferes with the comfortable enjoyment of life and property or tends to depreciate the value of the property of others cross reference definitions generally  12 prohibited it shall be unlawful for any person to cause permit maintain or allow the creation or maintenance of a nuisance illustrative enumeration the maintaining using placing depositing leaving or permitting to be or remain on any public or private property of any of the following items conditions or actions are hereby declared to be and constitute a nuisance  provided however that this enumeration shall not be deemed or construed to be conclusive limiting or restrictive 1 noxious weeds and other rank vegetation 2 the storage upon any property of building materials unless there is in force a valid building permit issued by the city for construction upon such property and such building materials are intended for use in connection with such construction building materials shall include but shall not be limited to lumber bricks concrete or cinder blocks plumbing materials electrical wiring or equipment shingles mortar concrete or cement nails screws or any other materials used in constructing any structure all unused building materials shall be removed from the premises by the contractor prior to issuance of any occupancy permit or final acceptance by the building inspector 3 the storage or accumulation of junk trash rubbish or refuse of any kind except domestic refuse stored in such a manner as not to create a nuisance the term junk shall include parts of machinery or motor vehicles unused stoves or other appliances stored in the open remnants of wood metal or any other material or other castoff material of any kind whether or not the same could be put to any reasonable use 4 storage on any property of junk vehicles except in a completely enclosed building for the purposes of this article the term junk vehicles shall include any motor vehicle which is inoperative for any reason such as being in a state of disassembly disrepair stripped dismantled unregistered or unlicensed 5 the existence of any structure or damaged partial structure which because of fire wind or other natural disaster or physical deterioration is no longer habitable if a dwelling nor useful for any other purpose for which it may have been intended 6 the existence of any vacant building garage or other outbuilding unless such buildings are kept securely locked windows kept glazed or neatly boarded up and otherwise protected to prevent entrance thereto by vandals 7 the existence of any incomplete structures unless such structure is in the course of construction in accordance with a valid and subsisting building permit issued by the city and unless such construction is completed within a reasonable time 8 any condition which provides harborage for rats mice snakes and other vermin 9 all unnecessary or unauthorized noises and annoying vibrations including animal noises 10 all disagreeable or obnoxious odors and stenches as well as the conditions substances or other causes which give rise to the emission or generation of such odors and stenches 11 the carcasses of animals or fowl not disposed of within a reasonable time after death 12 the pollution of any public well or cistern stream lake canal or body of water by sewage dead animals creamery industrial wastes or other substances 13 any building structure or other place or location where any activity which is in violation of local state or federal law is conducted performed or maintained 14 any accumulation of stagnant water permitted or maintained on any lot or piece of ground 15 dense smoke noxious fumes gas soot or cinders in unreasonable quantities notice to abate whenever a nuisance is found to exist within the city the city manager shall give ten days written notice to the owner or occupant of the property upon which the nuisance exists or upon the person causing or maintaining the nuisance contents of notice the notice to abate a nuisance issued under the provisions of this article shall contain 1 an order to abate the nuisance or to request a hearing within a stated time which shall be reasonable under the circumstances 2 the location of the nuisance if the nuisance is stationary 3 a description of what constitutes the nuisance 4 a statement of acts necessary to abate the nuisance 5 a statement that if the nuisance is not abated as directed and no request for hearing is made within the prescribed time the city will abate such nuisance and assess the cost thereof against such person service of notice the notice to abate a nuisance shall be served as any other legal process may be served pursuant to law abatement by city upon the failure of the person upon whom notice to abate a nuisance was served pursuant to the provisions of this article to abate the nuisance the city shall proceed to abate such nuisance and shall prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof emergency abatement by city when in the opinion of the city manager there is actual and immediate danger to the public or occupants of a particular premises caused by a nuisance on such premises the city manager is hereby authorized and empowered without any notice or hearing to order and require such premises to be vacated the city manager shall immediately post the premises warning of the dangerous condition and shall then abate such nuisance and prepare a statement of costs incurred in the abatement thereof citys costs any and all costs incurred by the city in the abatement of a nuisance under the provisions of this article shall constitute a lien against the property upon which such nuisance existed which costs shall be collected as ad valorem taxes violation and penalties the violation of any provision of this article by any firm corporation person or persons or anyone acting on behalf of said person persons firm or corporation is a municipal civil infraction for which the fine shall be not less than $7500 for the first offense not less than $10000 for any offense which is a first repeat offense and not less than $25000 for any offense for which is a second repeat offense or any subsequent repeat offense plus in all cases the costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance 1 the imposition of any sentence shall not exempt the offender from compliance with the requirements of this article 2 any violation of this article is a nuisance per say and may be abated by the circuit court relief 3 for purposes of this section the term subsequent offense shall mean a violation of the provisions of this article committed by the same person firm corporation or anyone acting on behalf of said person firm or corporation within 365 calendar days of a previous violation of the same provision for which the person firm corporation or anyone acting on behalf of said person firm or corporation admitted responsibility or was found responsible by the court 4 each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense offenses committed on subsequent days within a period of seven calendar days following the issuance of a citation for a first offense shall all be considered separate first offenses  secs 468146100  reserved article v  oil and gas business of oil and gas acquisition production and storage deemed hazardous a the business and occupation of drilling and exploring for producing obtaining transporting gathering and storing of oil gas petroleum and hydrocarbons within the corporate limits of the city is hereby deemed a hazardous and dangerous business and occupation it is deemed necessary that such business and occupation be regulated controlled and limited for the purpose of providing protection for the lives health welfare and safety of the citizens of the city and of the public generally and for the protection of property from the danger of fire explosion gas leaks nuisances and other hazards injurious to the public peace health welfare and safety b the provisions of this article shall be deemed to be the minimum requirements for the preservation of the public peace health safety and welfare and compliance with all terms thereof shall not be deemed to relieve any person from any duty imposed by law to use all necessary care and take all necessary precautions for the safeguarding of the public peace health and safety and the rights of any individual or group of individuals it shall be the duty of any person drilling operating or maintaining any well to use all necessary care and take all precautions of whatsoever nature which shall be reasonably necessary under the circumstances to protect the public or the rights of any part thereof c words used in this article unless otherwise defined shall have the common meaning of such words as generally understood in the oil and gas industry unless the content in this article clearly implies or other hydrocarbons at such hearing all persons interested may be heard the council shall keep a record of its proceedings as regards the granting of the permits and the hearings thereon and may require the pooling of properties or parts thereof within the area or areas to be drilled and shall make any and all reasonable requirements necessary to protect and safeguard the rights of all reasons the drilling of any oil or gas well will be serious disadvantage or hazard to the city and its inhabitants as a whole it shall be discretionary with the council to grant or deny a permit in any industrial area or in any area in which residences or other buildings may have been erected when the granting of the permit shall be creative of fire hazards or otherwise destructive of property interests iic 5861 samebond required a the application shall also be accompanied by and no permit for the drilling of any well shall be issued without a duly executed bond given by the applicant as such penalties iih 5861 location and spacing of wells a the minimum drilling unit for the permittee to drill any well for the discovery or production of oil or gas shall be in accordance with spacing orders established by the state department of conservation for the area subject to limitations set forth in this section b the drilling location of any well shall in no instance be nearer than 300 feet from any street line alley line or railroad rightofway line c the drilling location of any well shall in each instance be at least 300 feet from the location of any building of the value in excess of $50000 existent at the time of commencement of actual drilling operations d no well shall be located within any of the streets alleys or rightsofway of the city or so located as to block or incumber or obstruct the use of any street alley or rightofway in any drilling or producing operations except by previous consent having been given by order of the city supervisor of wells and in such event for the limited period only e if it shall appear from the application on file and after notice and hearing thereon as in section 46105 provided that the limitation and restrictions established in this section will preclude drilling and operating in an area which should reasonably be drilled and operated the council shall be authorized and empowered to make exception from such limitations and restrictions iii 5861 production and operation a precautions and standard equipment and procedures to be utilized in drilling for oil and gas petroleum or other hydrocarbons and the production thereof the permittee shall use every precaution equipment and materials in accordance with approved methods of operation drilling and production to stop and prevent waste of oil gas petroleum or hydrocarbons and to protect residents and properties of the city and therein shall equip and operate the well and all allied equipment therewith of standard design and quality as are in common use in the petroleum industry all such equipment shall be installed and maintained in accordance with standard drilling producing and operating practices b fencing of drilling operation from the time of placing any equipment derricks riggings or other drilling equipment or supplies until the time of removal thereof upon final completion of the well each location of the well shall be completely surrounded by fencing in order to completely surround and enclose the drilling operation such fence shall be supported by steel posts and shall be of woven wire of not less than 14gauge wire with mesh of not less than two inches nor more than four inches and shall be at least six feet high c erection and location of flares  fencing all flares erected within the corporate limits of the city shall be at least 300 feet from any building or structure and shall extend at least 20 feet above the surface of the ground all such flares shall be of approved construction and shall be installed in a pit of sufficient depth and area to provide adequate drainage and safety precautions the location of all such flares shall be completely enclosed by steel fencing of the same type and dimensions as provided in subsection b of this section for enclosing the drilling operation d use of portable slush pit required in all cases where an oil and gas well is being drilled in a residentially zoned area the drilling operator shall use a portable slush pit and all slush and waste shall be deposited therein and from time to time removed beyond the corporate limits of the city for disposal no open pits for the disposal of slush brine or salt water shall be permitted at any time after the completion of the drilling operation in any area of the city e disposal of brine or salt water all brine or salt water produced in the drilling for or production of oil shall under the supervision of the state supervisor of wells be returned to some underground formation or otherwise disposed of in order that such brine salt water or refuse shall not do damage to any fresh water wells lakes ponds or rivers f well enclosure to be kept clean  free of inflammables the person in charge of the producing operations of a well shall keep the fenced enclosure around such well free of all trash and inflammable substances not necessary in the operation of such well and shall keep the weeds cut and otherwise keep the location in a clean and orderly condition machinery and equipment not used in the operation of the well shall not be stored or left in such enclosure all oil tanks shall be painted or galvanized g removal of mud or fluid from well  notification of fire chief except in emergency at least six hours before any mud or fluid in any well shall be removed swabbed baled or otherwise cleaned out the chief of the fire department or other officer in charge shall be served with written notice of the hour that such cleaning swabbing or bailing is done and if in his opinion the cleaning swabbing or bailing shall be hazardous to the safety of life or property he is hereby authorized to stop or prevent such cleaning swabbing or bailing until such time as conditions may become favorable to continue the same it shall be unlawful to commence the testing of any well from sundown until sunrise or during a period when gas may settle on the ground or during any electrical storm before bringing in a well all of the control devices including master gates and safety valves shall be tested and shall be in good working order and shall comply with the provisions of this article h drilling procedure for salinaniagara formation prior to entering the top of the salinaniagara formation the drilling shall be done with mudladen fluids of such weight and viscosity as shall be required by and under good drill practices in the area in which such drilling is being done iv 5861 equipment a separator each well shall have a separator capable of caring adequately for the production of the well and both oil and gas without spraying oil separator vent line no gas shall be produced wasted or allowed to escape separator vent line from any well when it shall appear that an explosive mixture of gas may be accumulating near the ground the designated city officer in charge may require that the well be shut down until such gas is dissipated b storage tanks within corporate limits no tank or other facility for the storage of oil gas petroleum or hydrocarbons produced from any well within the corporate limits of the city shall be kept erected or maintained within the corporate limits of the city except in areas zoned as industrial and agricultural areas where such storage tanks shall be allowed such storage tanks shall be erected without the corporate limits of the city except for such installation in industrially and agriculturally zoned areas and shall be connected to any well by pipes or pipelines by the nearest possible route c storage tanks in industrial and agricultural zones all tanks for the storage of oil permitted to be installed in industrially and agriculturally zoned areas shall be located in a pit and encircled by an embankment and fire wall with a capacity of 112 times the capacity of the tank no tank shall be located nearer than 300 feet from any building or industrial structure d pipes and pipelines all pipes or pipelines leading to or from a well location shall be buried underground to a minimum depth of 24 inches below normal surface of the ground and before a pipe line is laid in down or along a street the person or company laying such line shall deposit with the city treasurer the sum of $030 per foot for the laying of such line and in the construction of such lines the permittee shall pay to the city all damages sustained by it by reason of the construction of the lines and the repair of any streets crossed by or extending along such pipelines in an amount sufficient to place the city property in the same condition as prior to the laying of the lines and shall pay to the city any and all damage incident to the taking up or repairing of the lines thereafter no concrete or asphalt paving shall be cut or disturbed unless absolutely necessary and then only under the supervision of the city the permittee shall be required to replace and repair the paving at his own expense and under the supervision of the city manager e rigs and heavy machinery  moving permit required no rigs or heavy machinery used in connection with the drilling or operation of wells in the city shall be moved over city streets from one location to another without obtaining a permit therefor which permit shall set forth the streets which may be used for the purpose and the same shall be transported under the supervision of the city manager f pumping units all pumping units installed shall be electrically operated and properly housed and so enclosed as to protect the public therefrom all electrical switches and electrical outlets shall be enclosed and shall be explosion proof v 5861 restoration  abandonment a plugging upon abandonment upon the discontinuance of the drilling operations or the production of any oil or gas from any working well the well shall be abandoned and plugged under the supervision of the state supervisor of wells b commencement of plugging all plugging operations on all dry or abandoned wells shall commence within 60 days after drilling production operations shall have ceased and shall be carried to completion c filling pits and cellars the permittee shall fill all pits and cellars with dirt and level off the surface and restore the pits and cellars as nearly as possible to its condition prior to the commencement of the drilling operation all equipment shall be removed from the location promptly and all machinery tanks pipes and tools shall be transported from the well site embankments leveled and the surface of the land restored to its former condition d removal of substances contributing to fire or pollution hazard the permittee shall not permit any undue accumulation of slush salt water or oil or any other offensive or dangerous substances to accumulate and upon the completion of the well shall remove and eliminate all debris and eliminate all conditions and circumstances contributing to the hazard of fire or pollution vi 5861 deepening reworking of well if any person owner producer or operator shall desire to deepen or extend a well below the depth of its original objective he shall make application to the council as if an original application for a permit were taken in such deepening and reworking the same precautions shall be complied with as set forth in this article if such application for reworking or deepening shall be filed within 60 days from the date of the completion or abandonment of the original drilling operation a fee of $20000 rather than of $50000 shall be required vii 5861 compliance and abatement a the chief of the fire department or the city manager city supervisor of wells or such other employee of the city as shall be designated for that purpose by the council shall have the right and privilege at any time to enter upon the premises covered by any permit issued under this article for the purpose of making inspections thereof to determine if the requirements of this article are complied with or the requirements of any other ordinance of the city met relating to the health welfare and safety of persons within the city b all drilling operations for the discovery of oil gas petroleum or other hydrocarbons equipping of wells producing and marketing of oil gas petroleum and hydrocarbons plugging of wells and all material used and work done in connection with the exploring for producing and marketing of petroleum products shall be in conformity with all state and federal laws and statutes and rules and regulations pertaining thereto and particularly with the state statutes and the regulations of the state supervisor of wells secs 4611746135  reserved article vi  blight purpose of article the purpose of this article is to preserve and protect the public health safety and general welfare of persons and property within the city by preventing reducing andor eliminating blight and potential blight in the city by the prevention and elimination of certain environmental and other causes of blight or blighting factors which exist or which may in the future exist within the city  41080 enabling authority this article is adopted in accordance with and pursuant to act no 344 of the public acts of michigan of 1945 mcl 12871 et seq as amended and in accordance with and pursuant to the city charter  41080 definitions the following words terms and phrases when used in this article shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning building materials means but shall not be limited to lumber bricks concrete or order blocks plumbing materials electrical wiring or equipment heating ducts or equipment shingles mortar concrete or cement structural or miscellaneous steel nails screws or any other materials used in building or constructing any structure and in any other manner of construction inoperable means incapable of being operated or propelled under its own power by reason of dismantling disrepair or other cause for a period in excess of ten days junk means but shall not be limited to parts of machinery or motor vehicles unused stoves refrigerators or other appliances stored in the open remnants of woods metal or any other material or castoff material of any kind whether or not the same could be put to any reasonable use junk automobile junk motordriven vehicle trailer in disrepair contractors equipment in disrepair or boat in disrepair means such automobile vehicle trailer equipment or boat which is inoperable or partially dismantled partially dismantled means that parts which are ordinarily components have been removed or are missing unlicensed vehicle means any vehicle without a valid current state motor vehicle license  41080 cross reference definitions generally  12 enforcement of article this article shall be enforced under the direction of the city manager in coordination with his designated enforcement officer  41080 causes  prohibitions it is hereby determined that the following uses structures conditions and activities constitute blight andor are causes of blight or blighting factors which if allowed to exist will tend to result andor actually result in blighted and undesirable neighborhoods and areas within the city no person shall maintain cause to be maintained or permit to be maintained any of these conditions and causes of blight or blighting factors upon any property or waters in the city owned leased rented or occupied by such person 1 in any area except where specifically permitted by law the storage upon any property andor waters of unlicensed vehicles junk automobiles junk motordrive vehicles trailers in disrepair contractors equipment in disrepair or boats in disrepair except in a completely enclosed building 2 in any area except where specifically permitted by law the storage upon any property of building materials unless there is in force a valid building permit issued by the city for construction upon the property and such materials are intended for use in connection with such construction 3 in any area except where specifically permitted by law the storage or accumulation of junk trash rubbish garbage debris paper glass dirt cans bottles litter waste material of any kind or refuse of any kind except domestic refuse stored in a rodentproof receptacle in such a manner so as not to create a public nuisance for a period not to exceed ten days 4 in any area the existence of any structure or part of any structure which because of fire wind or other natural disaster or because of physical deterioration is no longer habitable if a dwelling or useful for any other purpose for which it may have been intended 5 in any area the existence of any vacant dwelling garage or other outbuilding unless such buildings are kept securely locked windows kept glazed or neatly boarded up and otherwise protected to prevent entrance thereto by vandals or trespassers 6 in any area the existence of any partially completed structure unless such structure is in the course of construction in accordance with a valid building permit issued by the city and unless such construction is completed within the life of the building permit or a valid extension thereof  41080 service of notice the owner if possible and the lessor lessee or occupant of any property of which or upon which blight the causes of blight or blighting factors set forth in section 46140 are found to exist shall be notified in writing to remove or eliminate such blight causes of blight or blighting factors from such property within ten days after service of notice in one of the following ways 1 by delivering the notice to the owner lessor lessee or occupant personally or by leaving the notice at his residence office or place of business with some person of suitable age and discretion  2 by mailing the notice by certified or registered mail to such owner lessor lessee or occupant at his last known address  or 3 if the owner lessor lessee or occupant is unknown by posting the notice in some conspicuous place on the premises for five days failure by the owner lessor lessee or occupant to comply with such notice within the time allowed shall constitute a violation of this article  41080 nuisance per se any violation of this article shall constitute a nuisance per se upon application of the city to any court of competent jurisdiction the court may order the nuisance abated andor the violation of this article and continuation of the nuisance restrained and enjoined  41080 violation and penalties the violation of any provision of this article by any firm corporation person or persons or anyone acting on behalf of said person persons firm or corporation is a municipal civil infraction for which the fine shall be not less than $7500 for the first offense not less than $10000 for any offense which is a first repeat offense and not less than $25000 for any offense for which is a second repeat offense or any subsequent repeat offense plus in all cases the costs and other sanctions allowed by law or ordinance 1 the imposition of any sentence shall not exempt the offender from compliance with the requirements of this article 2 any violation of this article is a nuisance per se and may be abated by the circuit court relief 3 for purposes of this section the term subsequent offense shall mean a violation of the provisions of this article committed by the same person firm corporation or anyone acting on behalf of said person firm or corporation within 365 calendar days of a previous violation of the same provision for which the person firm corporation or anyone acting on behalf of said person firm or corporation admitted responsibility or was found responsible by the court 4 each day that a violation is permitted to exist shall constitute a separate offense offenses committed on subsequent days within a period of seven calendar days following the issuance of a citation for a first offense shall all be considered separate first offenses  secs 4614446150  reserved article vii  wellhead protection area footnotes  2  editors note ivii adopted  repealed the former art vii  4615146157 and enacted a new art vii as set out herein the former art vii pertained to similar subject matter and derived from ivii 12102  ivii 7102 introduction the city of richmond macomb county recognizes a that residents of the city of richmond rely exclusively on groundwater for a safe drinking water supply and b that certain land uses particularly those located within the wellhead protection area whpa that use hazardous substances can contaminate groundwater the purpose of the whpa ordinance is to protect water quality to keep pollutants from entering surface and groundwater to reduce the danger of contamination and to protect potable water supplies it is the intent of the city of richmond to protect the whpa as much as possible education and securing public cooperation where new uses or modifications to existing uses are proposed it is important that every precaution be taken to secure the citys future water supply consequently appropriate land use regulations will be imposed in addition to those imposed in the zoning ordinance or in other city county state or federal regulations i 82106 definitions aquifer a geological formation group of formations or part of a formation capable of storing and yielding groundwater to wells and springs contamination an impairment of water quality by chemicals radio nuclides biologic organisms or other extraneous matter whether or not it affects the potential or intended beneficial use of water design and performance standards structural measures determined to be the most effective practical means of preventing or reducing pollution inputs from point or non point sources development the carrying out of any construction reconstruction alteration of surface or structure or change of land use or intensity of use environment means a the navigable waters the waters of the contiguous zone and the ocean waters of which the natural resources are under the exclusive management authority of the united states under the fishery conservation and management act of 197 and b any other surface water groundwater drinking water supply land surface or subsurface strata or ambient air within the united states or under the jurisdiction of the united states 40 cfr  3023 facility something built installed or established for a particular purpose hazardous substances means one or more of the following 1 any substance that the mdeq determines to pose an unacceptable risk to the public health safety welfare or the environment considering the fate of the material doseresponse toxicity or adverse impact on natural resources 2 as defined in the comprehensive environmental response compensation and liability act of 198 public law 96510 94 stat 27673 this definition does not include 1 gasoline oil or other vehicle fluids contained in vehicles traversing or parked at a property on a shortterm basis 2 storage of hazardous substances for retail sale in packaging and in quantities consistent with use by occupants of residential dwellings primary containment a tank pit container pipe or vessel of first containment of a liquid or chemical property owner a person public corporation authority or a political subdivision of the state or a combination of any of them that holds an ownership interest in land whether recorded or not an ownership interest means ownership by one person or by different private entities if the land is owned in joint interest or by members of the same immediate family release any unplanned or improper discharge leak or spill of a potential contaminant including a hazardous material secondary containment a second tank catchment pit pipe or vessel that limits and contains liquid or chemical leaking or leaching from a primary containment area  monitoring and recovery are required significant use means the use storage handling or management at any time of hazardous substances in quantities that exceed those commonly used for typical residential or office purposes underground storage tanks usts an underground storage tank is one or any combination of tanks including the underground pipes connected hereto used to contain an accumulation of hazardous substances the volume of which including the volume of the underground pipes connected thereto is ten percent or more beneath the surface of the ground the term ust does not include any of the following  pipeline facilities including gathering lines regulated under the natural gas pipeline safety act of 196 82 stat 720 49 usca 2001 3 as amended  surface impoundments pits ponds or lagoons  storm or waste water collection systems  flowtanks  storage tanks in underground areas where the tanks are on or above the surface of the floor and the integrity of the tank is periodically visually evaluated  septic tanks  tanks used for storingheating fuel for consumptive use on the premises where stored provided the premises are single or twofamily homes wellhead protection area the area which has been approved by the mdeq in accordance with the state of michigan wellhead protection program which represents the surface and subsurface area surrounding a water well or well field which supplies a public water system and contaminants are reasonably likely to move toward and reach the water well or well field within a tenyear time of travel defined by reference on a map approved by the mdeq ii 82106 general provisions property owners and facility operators of all newly proposed projects within the wellhead protection area must comply with the design and performance standard requirements of this article and with the requirements of all state federal county and other local regulations wellhead protection area boundaries wellhead protection area boundaries are on the wellhead protection area map that is part of this article this area may be periodically updated without modification to the ordinance iii 82106 design and performance standards the purpose of design and performance standards is to protect water quality to keep pollutants from entering surface and groundwater to reduce the danger of contamination and to protect potable water supplies performance standards regulate development within the whpa by enforcing specific standards for facility design and construction they allow for aggressive protection of the whpa by striving for quality development within the whpa performance standards can be complex to administer they require considerable evaluation and analysis to determine the relative impact to the whpa all design and performance standards should be prepared by registered professional engineers the following standards will apply to uses in the whpa 1 cooling systems any cooling water from solvent recovery systems should be free of contamination from solvent metals or other pollutants and should not be discharged to the ground closedloop cooling systems are encouraged to eliminate cooling water discharges cooling water may be discharged into a storm sewer sanitary sewer or stream provided all federal state and local requirements are met 2 construction activities appropriate maintenance and equipment storage areas must be identified on the site plan where possible before any construction is done on the site if construction equipment is to be stored in an open area ie temporary storage  the site should not be within the drip line of trees  the site should not be within 100 feet of a watercourse or wetland runoff should be diverted away from watercourses and wetlands  special measures must be taken to prevent excess solids suspended in storm water from being discharged from the site  all applicable state and local soil erosion requirements must be met  the maintenance repair cleaning and storage of construction machinery vehicles and equipment should be confined to areas specifically designed and designated for that purpose this practice includes both open and covered equipment maintenance and storage areas and emphasizes the importance of controlling runoff from both kinds of storage areas this practice should be implemented at all equipment maintenance and storage areas and whenever construction will be ongoing long enough that construction equipment will need to be stored serviced maintained or repaired on a construction site appropriate equipment maintenance and storage sites should be identified before any actual construction begins heavy equipment should be well maintained to prevent leaks  make sure waste materials are properly disposed of  outside equipmentmaintenance storage areas should be inspected daily to ensure equipment isnt being stored within the drip line of trees and to ensure the vehicles and equipment arent leaking periodic checks of the equipment wash area should also be done to ensure it is not failing additional stone may be needed to maintain the wash area  construction sites must provide facilities for containing any accidental losses of oil or other polluting substances and comply with the approved equipment maintenance and storage areas as identified on the site plan  at the conclusion of construction stabilize the surrounding area 3 crossconnections crossconnections such as sanitary discharges to storm sewers storm water discharges to sanitary sewers or floor drain discharges to storm sewer systems are prohibited 4 debris no potentially polluting material such as garbage trash refuse junk vehicles junk appliances or toxic substances may be dumped or stored outside a protected structure or container within the whpa 5 floor drains floor drain discharges to the ground septic systems except in sanitary facilities storm sewers or any surface water body from any location in the facility is prohibited floor drains in bathrooms kitchens and other sanitary facilities must either discharge to a septic system a municipal sanitary sewer or a holding tank which is periodically pumped out floor drains in work areas must be connected either to a holding tank with a gravity discharge pipe or to a collection sump which discharges to a holding tank floor drains are prohibited in rooms where boilers or emergency generators are housed 6 holding tanks interior hazardous substance storage tanks should have 110 percent secondary containment doublewalled construction alarms and overfill protection interior storage tanks should be installed in an enclosed area isolated from floor drains storm water sewers or other conduits which may cause a release into the environment for flood control all exterior aboveground tanks will include but not be limited to a monitoring system and secondary standpipe above the 100year flood control level for monitoring and recovery all aboveground tanks must have an impervious dike above the 100year flood level capable of containing 110 percent of the largest volume of storage and be provided with an overflow recovery catchment area or sump fillpipe inlets should be above the elevation of the top of the storage tank tanks and associated appurtenances should be tested periodically for structural integrity 7 liquid waste ponds open liquid waste ponds are prohibited 8 loading and unloading areas areas where hazardous substances and waste materials are loaded and unloaded should be enclosed or roofed areas with secondary containment should be isolated from floor drains to prevent potential spills from contaminating storm water or discharging to the ground loading and unloading areas must have impervious surfaces and be designed to prevent releases from incidental handling 9 material handling and storage areas material handling and storage areas for hazardous substances and waste materials should be permanently roofed completely confined within secondary confinement berms isolated from floor drains have sealed surfaces and should not be accessible to unauthorized personnel compatible drum and container storage areas should be located together for better control of hazardous substances and waste inventory 10 parking lots this design standard is intended to provide review criteria for parking areas so that approved construction techniques will prevent solids and contaminates from reaching groundwater and is applicable for nearly all parking areas the primary purpose for proper performance of parking lot design is to reduce peak runoff and provide some flood storage this helps reduce surface flushing and subsequent contamination parking lots can essentially function as specialized detention basins as such they should comply with the design and performance standards described under storm water management 11 secondary containment any facility involving the collection handling manufacture use storage transfer or disposal of any solid or liquid material or wastes which has the potential to contaminate groundwater must have a secondary containment system whose purpose is to intercept any leak or release from the primary containment vessel or structure containment systems must be accessible to allow for easy inspection secondary containment must be equivalent to 110 percent of the maximum amount of materials to be stored and be sufficient to retain the substance for the maximum anticipated time necessary for recovery and cleanup underground tanks or buried pipes carrying such materials must have double walls and inspectable sumps 12 septic systems and dry wells leach fields must be sized according to soil characteristics and hydraulic and pollutant loadings excessively sized septic system leach fields may cause reduced effectiveness if normal flows are inadequate to maintain a biologically active clogging layer throughout the leach field septic systems are not recommended in areas with karst fractured cavernous volcanic or any other highly permeable subsurface formation additional detention times for septic tanks and larger buffer zones around leach fields should be considered in septic system design all septic tank installations should be designed with provisions for sampling at the outlet baffle gas baffles should be installed at the outlet dry wells are prohibited unless they are only clean water discharges that meet all established minimum contaminant levels promulgated under the safe drinking water act and other state and federal standards for drinking water and meets all other state and local requirements flow restrictions and lowflow faucets for sinks and spray nozzles should be installed to minimize hydraulic loading to subsurface disposal systems 13 site design the project and related improvements must be designed to protect the natural environment there must be no impairment pollution andor destruction of water natural resources and the public trust earthen berms should be used to limit contact with the ground in spillprone areas specific areas should be designated and maintained for employee parking if equipment is to be stored in an open area ie temporary storage  the site should not be within the drip line of trees  the site should not be within 100 feet of a watercourse or wetland runoff should be diverted away from watercourses and wetlands if equipment is to be maintained and stored in a permanent structure ie building the building should not be located within 100 feet of a watercourse or wetland under no circumstances should buildings or equipment be located in flood plains stream beds or the channel of any watercourse equipment wash areas should discharge into a holding tank or sanitary sewer line depending on the amount of oil grease and other pollutants pretreatment of wastewater may be needed before it enters the sanitary sewer wash areas should be constructed of two to threeinch stone or other approved material with a minimum sixinch base they should be underlain with geotextile materials and protected using berms or diversions to prevent the runoff water from leaving the site secondary containment should be incorporated into the design of the maintenancestorage facility to contain spills from all hazardous materials buildings should be clustered as much as possible to retain open space surrounding vegetation tree cover and to minimize changes in topography minimum setback distances should be established between limits of septic systems dry wells holding tanks leach fields and wellheads distances should be based on information such as percolation tests zones of influence of leachate mounding wellhead protection areas and time of travel 14 storm water management storm water management must comply with all applicable federal state and local requirements storm water management and drainage facilities require special design requirements for highrisk areas such as whpas they must be designed to take advantage of existing natural retention and storage capacity of wetlands and water bodies or water courses and not increase flooding or the potential for environmental contamination the preferred strategy for storm water management is storage treatment and controlled surface water discharge treatment and infiltration may be employed as a storm water strategy if the site constraints prohibit the uses of the preferred strategy treatment refers to the planned use of natural and man made mechanisms to purify storm water out of solids separation and capture of oil and grease absorption of particulates and uptake of dissolved solids treatment of storm water is required prior to infiltration or controlled surface water discharge a surface water outlet is recommended when available the preferred management strategy consisting of storage treatment and controlled surface water discharge includes dual cell onsite detention basins extended dual cell detention basins or wet dualcell detention basins the secondary management strategy consisting of treatment and infiltration includes discharge to storm sewers catch basins oil and grit separators infiltration trenches lined grass swales or dual cell infiltration basins storm water contact with hazardous substances and waste materials must be avoided to the greatest extent possible storage of hazardous substances and waste materials should be isolated in roofed or enclosed areas to prevent contact with precipitation if exposure of storage areas to the elements is allowed uncovered storage areas should have a separate storm water collection system which discharges to a holding tank storm water from building roofs may be discharged to the ground however if solvent distillation equipment or vapor degreasing is used with a vent that exhausts to the roof then roof leaders may become cross contaminated with solvent these potential sources of cross contamination must be avoided crossconnections such as sanitary discharges to storm sewers storm water discharges to sanitary sewers or floor drain discharges to storm sewer systems are prohibited water from floor sumps may not be discharged to a storm sewer or stream runoff from equipment maintenancestorage areas should be directed to stabilized outlets designed to assimilate the volume and type of pollutants discharged to them 15 underground storage tanks underground storage tanks must comply with all applicable federal and state requirements underground storage tanks should not be used unless explicitly required by fire codes or other federal state or local regulations where underground tanks are required they should have doublewalled construction or secondary containment such as a concrete vault lined or sealed with an impermeable material and filled with sand both types of tanks should have appropriate secondary containment monitoring high level and leak sensing audiovisual alarms level indicators and overfill protection if a dip stick is used for level measurements there should be a protective plate or basket where the stick may strike the tank bottom for flood control all underground facilities will include but not be limited to a monitoring system and secondary standpipe above the 100year flood control level for monitoring and recovery 16 utilities where piping for utilities conduits ducts etc extend floor of any floors at or below grade the openings must be sealed with chemical resistant non cracking caulk 17 waste stream waste management techniques must comply with all applicable federal state and local requirements wastegenerating operations should be physically segregated from other operations and preferably be located within a confinement area with sealed floors and with no direct access outside the facility this reduces the total work area exposed to solvents facilitates waste stream segregation and efficient material and waste handling and minimizes cross contamination with other operations and potential pathways for release into the environment waste collection stations should be provided throughout work areas for the accumulation of spent chemicals soiled rags etc each station should have labeled containers for each type of waste fluid this provides safe interim storage of wastes reduces frequent handling of small quantities of wastes to storage areas and minimizes the overall risk of a release into the environment 18 work areas sealed floors are easier to clean without the use of solvents all floors should be constructed of cement or other impervious materials to prevent contaminants from leaching into the soils or groundwater floor surfaces in work areas and chemical storage areas should be sealed with an impermeable material resistant to acids caustics solvents oils or any other substance which may be used or generated at the facility work area floors should be pitched to appropriate floor drains if floor drains are not used or if they are located close to entrance ways then entrances must be designed to prevent storm water runoff from entering the building curbing and internal floor berms should be used to isolate floor drains from spillprone areas i 82106 site plan review standards the public service director is hereby appointed the whpa administrator to administer and implement the provisions of the city of richmond whpa ordinance the public service director is responsible for reviewing site plans within the whpa for compliance with the provisions of the whpa ordinance the public service director will review the plans in regards to whpa design and performance standards and may request any information or revisions required to meet those standards upon application for a site plan review for a use within the whpa the public service director may employ such technical expertise as needed to ensure compliance with the provisions of these regulations all reasonable costs as determined by the city of richmond incurred in the compliance review process shall be passed the applicant and shall be in addition to those fees normally charged to review an application for site plan reviews required by the zoning ordinance in addition to existing site plan application forms the applicants must complete and submit the site plan review environmental checklist as required by the citys wellhead protection plan in addition to the site plan requirements of the zoning ordinance site plans for sites within the whpa must also provide the following 1 secondary containment is required in all site areas where businesses industry and government agencies store handle or use hazardous materials in operational processes 2 floor drains are allowed only when connected to a publicly approved wastewater treatment system onsite holding tanks or other type of system approved by the municipality 3 storm water management plans must incorporate effective containment measures 4 special attention should be given to proper storm water and soil erosion control so that the removal of storm water will not increase offsite sedimentation or otherwise adversely impact neighboring properties flood or degrade water resources 5 parking areas must be designed to reduce nonpoint discharge of runoff and contain sediment traps to prevent contaminants from reaching groundwater 6 all storage areas for chemicals liquids and underground facilities must be identified as such on the plans after site plan approval no modifications can be made without review and approval as though it were a new application modified review procedures may be considered for project amendments it is equally important that projects be inspected regularly during construction to ensure that the project is being constructed as approved performance guarantees should be required in the amount of all required improvements additional requirements best management practices are intended to provide a measure of operational integrity these can be implemented in the form of an agreement at the beginning of a project or inspection program essentially the owner is expected to maintain a high level of site maintenance and uphold certain operational requirements i 82106 appeals a a whpa appeals board is hereby established by the city council to hear and render judgment on allegations of an error in any requirement decision or determination by the whpa administrator in the enforcement or administration of this ordinance the whpa appeals board shall not have the authority to grant variances to the requirements of this ordinance b the whpa appeals board shall be appointed by the city council and shall be comprised of three members who shall serve for fouryear terms commencing on september 1 of each year the members shall be  one member of the city council  one city residentatlarge  one individual city resident or nonresident knowledgeable in groundwater protection methods practices procedures and requirements c the whpa appeals board members shall formulate and adopt its own bylaws rules of procedure and evidence subject to approval of the city council d the whpa appeals board may meet on an as needed basis all meetings of this board shall be held pursuant to the open meetings act and the records maintained by the city clerk regarding appeals are public records subject to the freedom of information act e there shall be a fee for a hearing before the whpa appeals board said fee shall be set by the city council by resolution f any request for a hearing before the whpa appeals board must be submitted no later than 30 days following the decision of the whpa administrator for which the request is being submitted g the whpa appeals board shall render a decision on an appeal no later than 30 days following an appeals hearing the decision shall state the boards finding of fact and the reason for the boards decision h any person or persons aggrieved by the decision of whpa appeals board may appeal such decision to a court of competent jurisdiction i 82106 liability and enforcement a liability nothing in this article will be construed to imply that the city of richmond has accepted any of an ownerdevelopers liability if a permitted facility or use contaminates groundwater in any aquifer b civil enforcement 1 the public service director or authorized representative bearing proper identification shall be permitted to enter private property at any reasonable time with reasonable cause or with prior notification for such purposes as inspection observation measurement sampling and records examination pertaining to the requirements of this section upon request of the entity which is the object of the inspection and if permitted by the state public records law information obtained as a result shall be maintained as confidential if the owner or tenant does not consent to the entry of the public service director the public service director may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction of an appropriate warrant or other authority to enter said property but no consent is necessary for entry into areas then open to the public or to customers 2 any person may submit to this jurisdiction a verbal or written complaint alleging a violation of this article 3 upon receipt of a complaint the whpa administrator will conduct a brief investigation of the substances of the complaint including a meeting with the landowner involved 4 based upon the determination that there is a violation of this article the jurisdiction whpa administrator will conduct an informal reconciliation with the violator as part of such informal reconciliation the jurisdiction will  notify the violator by mail of the violation of this article and a desire of the jurisdiction to correct the violation reconciliation the statement will also indicate that should the violator refuse to comply with the recommended corrective actions within the time set forth by the jurisdiction action will be taken to compel the violator to correct the violation and the violator will be billed for the cost of compelling the corrective action enforcement action may include a stop work order on all areas of development covered under this article  make a good faith effort to meet the violator and resolvecorrect the violation 5 if after taking the steps above and after a period of 30 days following the mailing of the notice of the violation the jurisdiction in good faith determines that the violator is unwilling to participate in informal reconciliation and take the corrective actions prescribed the jurisdiction will notify the violator by mail of the termination of the informal reconciliation 6 the jurisdiction may take the corrective action prescribed above 30 days after notifying violator by mail of the notice of termination of the informal reconciliation and bill the violator for the reasonable cost of such action c criminal enforcement a person who is alleged to have violated this ordinance may be prosecuted for the commission of a crime violation of this article is a misdemeanor and may be punished by imprisonment of
