preliminary plat stage 2 of the subdivision prepared and certified as to its accuracy by a registered civil engineer or a registered land surveyor and prepared in conformance with the requirements of the subdivision act and this chapter and suitable for recording by the county register of deeds proprietor means a natural person firm association partnership corporation or combination of any of them which may hold any ownership of land whether recorded or not public reservation means a portion of a subdivision which is set aside for public use and made available for public use and acquisition electricity sewage disposal communication telegraph transportation or water public walkway means a dedicated public rightofway constructed of portland cement for the purpose of pedestrian access areas and located so as to connect to two or more streets or a street and a public land parcel street means any street avenue boulevard road lane parkway viaduct or other way which is an existing state county or city roadway  or a street or way shown in a plat heretofore approved pursuant to law or approved by official action  or a street or way on a plat duly filed and recorded in the office of the county register of deeds a street includes the land between the street lines whether improved or unimproved and comprises pavement shoulders gutters sidewalks parking areas and lawns streets in all subdivisions shall be constructed of asphalt with concrete curb and gutter in accordance with richmond engineering standards 1 major thoroughfare means an arterial street of great continuity which is intended to serve as a large volume trafficway for both the immediate city area and region beyond and may be designated in the citys major thoroughfare plan as a major thoroughfare parkway expressway or equivalent term to identify those streets comprising the basic structure of the street plan 2 street boulevard means a street developed to twolane oneway pavements separated by a median 3 street collector means a street used primarily to carry traffic from minor streets to major thoroughfares 4 street culdesac means a minor street of short length having one end open to traffic and being permanently terminated at the other end by a vehicular turnaround 5 street industrial means a street intended to serve primarily as a means of access within industrial subdivisions of industrial districts to a major thoroughfare and not intended to serve residential properties or to carry residential traffic 6 street marginal access means a minor street paralleling and adjacent to a major thoroughfare which provides access to abutting properties and protection from 7 street loop means a minor street of short length with two openings to traffic beginning from the same street and projecting parallel to each other and connecting at their termination by a loop 8 street minor means a street of limited continuity used primarily for access to abutting residential properties 9 street multiplefamily residential means a street intended to serve primarily the greater traffic demands of multiplefamily residential developments such streets may or may not have continuity within the overall thoroughfare plan 10 street trees mean trees that are required to be planted in the street rightofway along subdivision streets 11 street turnaround means a short boulevard street permanently terminated by a vehicular turnaround subdivision means the partitioning or dividing of a parcel or tract of land by the proprietor thereof or by his heirs executors administrators legal representatives successors or assigns for the purpose of sale or lease of more than one year or of building development that results in one or more parcels of less than 40 acres or the equivalent and that is not exempted by the state land division act act 288 of 196  subdivide or subdivision does not include a property transfer between two or more adjacent parcels if the property taken from one art i 8502 secs 8258231  reserved article ii  plats division 1  generally initial plat investigation a prior to the preparation and filing of a stage 1 tentative preliminary plat the proprietor may meet informally with the city manager city planner andor the planning commission in order that he may become familiar with the procedures and standards of this chapter and with the proposals of the master plan as they affect the area in which the proposed subdivision is located the proprietor may present a conceptual plan for review at a planning commission meeting the proprietor should concern himself with the following factors 1 the proprietor shall secure a copy of the zoning ordinance subdivision regulations engineering specifications and other similar ordinances or controls relative to the subdivision and improvement of land so as to make himself aware of the requirements of the municipality 2 the area for the proposed subdivision shall be properly zoned for the intended use 3 an investigation of the adequacy of existing schools and the adequacy of public open spaces including parks and playgrounds to serve the proposed subdivision shall be made by the proprietor 4 the relationship of the proposed subdivision with respect to major thoroughfares and plans for widening of thoroughfares shall be investigated by the proprietor 5 standards for sewage disposal water supply and drainage of the city and the health standards of the county and the state shall be investigated by the proprietor 6 the subdivision control act act no 288 of the public acts of michigan of 1967 mcl  et seq as amended and the requirements of those county and state agencies which are required by such public act to review and approve the plat shall be reviewed by the proprietor b the proprietor is encouraged to submit a preliminary or initial plat seven copies to the county plat coordinating committee for its review and comment art ii 8502 threephase approval process the preparation of a subdivision for platting shall be carried out phases or stages 1 stage 1 tentative preliminary approval 2 stage 2 final preliminary approval 3 stage 3 final approval art ii 8502 secs 82338240  reserved division 2  stage 1 tentative preliminary plat procedure for preparation and submittal the procedure under stage 1 for preparation and submittal of a tentative preliminary plat of the land area to be subdivided shall be as follows 1 filing a ten copies of the tentative preliminary plat of the proposed subdivision together with written application in triplicate shall be submitted to the city clerk who shall forward them to the planning commission b submittal to the city clerk shall be at least 45 days prior to the regular planning commission meeting which meeting shall be considered as the date of filing at which the proprietor will be scheduled to appear should any of the required data be omitted the applicant will be notified of the additional data required and commission action shall be delayed until the data is received 2 identification and description the stage 1 tentative preliminary plat shall include a proposed name of subdivision b location by section town and range or by other legal description c name and address of the proprietor and an indication of the proprietors interest in the land d name address and seal of the registered land surveyor or registered professional engineer responsible for the design layout and preparation of the plat e scale of plat one inch equals 100 feet as minimum acceptable scale f date of preparation g northpoint h any information required by the subdivision act or by the administrative rules of the state department of treasury state highways natural resources and public health and of the county drain commissioner as they relate to the act 3 existing conditions the stage 1 tentative preliminary plat shall include a an overall area map at a scale of not less than one inch equals 800 feet showing the relationship of the subdivision to its surroundings such as section lines andor major streets or collector streets and schools parks shopping centers and other community facilities the location map shall include at least that area which lies within onehalfmile of the subdivision boundary in all directions b boundary line of proposed subdivision section or corporation lines within or adjacent to the tract and overall property dimensions c property lines of adjacent tracts of subdivided and unsubdivided land shown in relation to the tract being proposed for subdivision including those of areas across abutting roads d location widths and names of existing or prior platted streets and private streets and public easements within or adjacent to the tract being proposed for subdivision including those located across abutting roads e location of existing sewers water mains storm drains and other underground facilities within or adjacent to the tract being proposed for subdivision f topography including natural and manmade features vegetation and contours all trees larger than three inches in diameter shall be identified contour interval shall be two feet with contours extending a minimum of 150 feet beyond the boundary of the plat topography to be based on usgs datum benchmarks for the work shall be indicated on the plat g the school board or school board superintendent of the school district having jurisdiction in the area concerned shall be informed and made aware of the proposed tentative preliminary plat by the proprietor a letter or document from the school board or school board superintendent indicating awareness of the proprietors intentions or a certified letter receipt from the applicant showing that the school board or school board superintendent was notified shall be submitted to the planning commission as part of the tentative preliminary plat 4 proposed conditions the stage 1 tentative preliminary plat shall include a layout of streets indicating proposed street names rightofway width and connection with adjoining platted streets and also the widths and location of easements and public walkways b layout numbers and scale dimensions of lots including building setback lines showing dimensions c indication and description of parcels of land intended to be dedicated or set aside for public use or for the use of property owners in the subdivision or for future street connections to adjacent tracts or as major drainage easements when such are determined by the city engineer to be necessary d an indication of the ownership and existing and proposed use of any parcels identified as excepted on the preliminary plat if the proprietor has an interest in or owns any parcel so identified as excepted the preliminary plat shall indicate how this property could be developed in accordance with the requirements of the existing zoning district in which it is located and with an acceptable relationship to the layout of the proposed tentative preliminary plat e an indication of system and easements proposed for sewage by a method approved by the council and the municipal engineer f an indication of system and easement proposed for water supply by a method approved by the council and the municipal engineer g an indication of proposed storm drainage and point of outlet at the subdivision line by a method approved by the council and the municipal engineer and if involving county drains the proposed drainage shall be acceptable to the county drain commissioner h in the case where the proprietor wishes to subdivide a given area but wishes to begin with only a portion of the total area the tentative preliminary plat shall include the proposed general layout for the entire area the part which is proposed to be subdivided first shall be clearly superimposed upon the overall plan in order to illustrate clearly the method of development which the proprietor intends to follow each subsequent plat shall follow the same procedure until the entire area controlled by the proprietor is subdivided i if the subdivisions is proposed to be developed under the subdivision open space plan the subdivision shall meet the requirements of section 82126 j an indication of the required underground utilities k an indication of the land to be used for parks playgrounds or recreational purposes 5 stage 1 tentative preliminary plat review by planning commission a the clerk shall receive and check for completeness the tentative preliminary plat as required by this chapter if complete and basically in conformance with applicable municipal requirements the clerk shall place the proposal on the agenda of the next months regular commission meeting b the clerk shall transmit a copy of the tentative preliminary plat to the municipal engineer and municipal planner for their technical review and recommendation c the commission shall review all details of the proposed subdivision within the framework of the zoning ordinance within the various elements of the master plan and within the standards of this chapter d the commission shall approve conditionally disapprove or approve the stage 1 tentative preliminary plat i should the approval be a conditional approval the tentative preliminary plat shall not be forwarded to the council until the conditions have been satisfied by the proprietor ii should the commission disapprove the tentative preliminary plat it shall record the reasons in the minutes of the regular meeting a copy of the minutes shall be sent to the proprietor and the school board or school board superintendent of the school district having jurisdiction in the area concerned iii should the commission find that all conditions have been satisfactorily met it may give approval to the tentative preliminary plat the chairman shall make a notation to that effect on each copy of the tentative preliminary plat and distribute copies as follows i return one copy to the proprietor  ii retain one copy which shall become a matter of permanent record in the commission files  iii forward one copy to the school board or school superintendent of the school district having jurisdiction in the area concerned  iv forward the remaining four copies to the council via the clerks office for informational purposes 6 stage 1 tentative preliminary plat review by city council a the council will not review a tentative preliminary plat until it has received the review and recommendations of the planning commission following the receipt of such recommendations the council shall consider the tentative preliminary plat at such meeting that the matter is placed on the regularly scheduled agenda b should the council approve the tentative preliminary plat it shall record its approval on the plat and return one copy to the proprietor c tentative preliminary approval shall not constitute final preliminary plat approval d tentative preliminary plat approval by the council shall be effective for a period of 12 months should the final preliminary plat in whole or in part not be submitted for final preliminary plat approval within this time limit the tentative preliminary plat must again be submitted to the commission for approval unless an extension is applied for by the proprietor and such request in writing is granted by the council e no installation or construction of any improvements shall be made on the basis of stage 1 tentative preliminary plat approval art ii 8502 secs 82428250  reserved division 3  stage 2 final preliminary plat procedure for clerk one to the planning commission and one to the building department the five true mylar copies or as per rules of procedure established by the state department of treasury shall be forwarded to the clerk of the county plat board art ii 8502 secs 82628270  reserved article iii  design layout standards division 1  generally conditions of approval the subdivision design layout standards set forth under this article are conditions of approval for plats complete plans for the construction of all streets utilities drainage and grading prepared by a registered civil engineer shall be submitted with the preliminary plat all final plans must be reviewed and approved by the council art iii 8502 secs 82728280  reserved division 2  streets conformance requirements streets shall conform to at least all minimum requirements of the general specifications and typical cross sections as set forth in this article city engineering standards and other conditions set forth by the council 1 location and arrangements a the proposed subdivision shall conform to the various elements of the master plan and shall be considered in relation to the existing and planned major thoroughfares and collector streets and shall be platted in the location and width indicated on such plan b the street layout shall provide for continuation of collector streets in adjoining subdivisions or the proper projection of streets when adjoining property is not subdivided  or shall conform to a plan for a neighborhood unit drawn up and adopted by the commission c the street layout shall include minor streets so laid out that their use by shall be discouraged d should a proposed subdivision border on or contain an existing or proposed major thoroughfare the commission may require marginal access streets reverse frontage with an approved screen planting contained in a nonaccess reservation along the rear property line having a minimum width of 15 feet or with side lot lines parallel to the major traffic street or such other treatment as may be necessary for adequate protection of residential properties and to afford separation and reduction of traffic hazards e should a proposed subdivision border on or contain a railroad expressway or other limited access highway rightofway the commission may require the location of a street approximately parallel to and on each side of such rightofway at a distance suitable for the development of an appropriate use of the intervening land such as for parks in residential districts and may require separation treatment for the protection of pedestrians and residential properties such distances shall be determined with due consideration of the minimum distance required for approach grades to future grade separation f half streets shall be prohibited except where absolutely essential to the reasonable development of the subdivision in conformity with the other requirements of these regulations and where the commission finds it will be practicable to require the dedication of the other half when the adjoining property is developed wherever there exists adjacent to the tract to be subdivided a dedicated or platted and recorded half street the other half shall be platted g should a proposed subdivision border upon or contain an existing or proposed canal channel or drainageway the commission may require the location of the bridge facility suitable to permit the unimpeded flow of water and the passage of waterborne vehicles and may require separation treatment along the canal channel or drainageway to protect persons and property h the council shall reject a plat which is isolated or which isolates other lands from existing public streets unless suitable access is provided i the council shall reject a plat showing a street or road name duplicating one already in use in the city except in continuing a street or road the council shall also reject a plat showing the name of a new street or road that is so similar to one already in existence in the city that permitting such use in the subdivision may be confusing to the public j maximum length for residential culdesac streets shall generally be ten times the  reserved division 5  open spaces open space plan the following requirements apply in addition to all other requirements of this article where a tentative preliminary plat is filed for approval under the subdivision open space plan section of the zoning ordinance 1 statement of principles consideration by the commission and the council of proposed optional use of subdivision open space plan shall reflect the following basic principles a the subdivision open space section of the zoning ordinance provides an optional method of subdividing property and approval of any subdivision open space plan is subject to the discretion of the council b particular attention shall be given to the effect of a subdivision open space plan upon the immediate area where the character of that area has been established by previous development major attention shall be given by the commission and the council to the benefits to be derived by the residents of the proposed subdivision and the municipality because of the subdivision open space plan with minor consideration to be given to the proprietor 2 application for plan approval  contents the application for approval of the subdivision open space plan shall contain the following in addition to the information required by other sections of this article a a complete description of the land proposed to be dedicated to the municipality or to the common use of lot owners called open land in this division shall be provided including the following as a minimum i legal description of open land ii topographical survey of open land iii type of soil in open land iv description of natural features on open land strands of trees or other vegetation streams or other bodies of water etc v other relevant factors b the proposed plan of development of the open land shall be contained in the application and shall include the following as a minimum i the proposed manner in which the title to land and facilities is to be held by the owner of land in the subdivision ii the proposed manner of collection of maintenance costs financing cost or assessments so that nonpayment will constitute a lien on the property thus avoiding municipal responsibility in the future iii the proposed manner of regulating the use of the common facilities and areas so as to eliminate possible nuisances to other property owners and cause for enforcement by the governing unit iv the proposed method of notifying the municipality when any change is contemplated in plans that would affect the original specifications approved by the municipality v the proposed method of setting up assessments to cover contingencies insurance against casualty and liability and payment of taxes relating to these properties vi the proposed uses of open land and the proposed improvements which are to be constructed by the proprietor c the application shall contain a statement of the benefits to be realized by the residents of the proposed subdivision and the municipality by approval of the proposed subdivision open space plan with particular reference to the objectives stated in the zoning ordinance 3 approval if the commission is satisfied that the proposed subdivision open space plan meets the letter and spirit of the zoning ordinance and should be approved it shall recommend such approval to the council with the conditions upon which such approval should be based thereafter the council shall take action upon such application in accordance with section 8241 4 disapproval if the commission is not satisfied that the proposed subdivision open space plan meets the letter and spirit of the zoning ordinance or finds that the approval of the subdivision open space plan will be detrimental to existing development in the general area and should not be approved it shall communicate such disapproval to the council with the reasons therefore the proprietor shall be entitled to a hearing upon the proposal before the council upon written request therefore filed with the clerk 5 contract if the council gives approval to the proposed subdivision open space plan it shall instruct the municipal attorney to prepare a contract setting forth the conditions upon which such approval is based which contract after approval by the council shall be entered into between the municipality and the proprietor prior to the approval of the final preliminary plat based upon the approved tentative preliminary plat the proprietor shall provide copies of agreements covenants or other documents showing the manner in which areas to be reserved for the common use of residents of the subdivision are to be maintained and used art iii 8502 public reservations when consideration is given by the proprietor to the allocation of area suitable located and of adequate iii 8502 floodplains any areas of land within the proposed subdivision which lie either wholly or in part within the floodplain of a river stream creek or lake or any other areas which are subject to flooding or inundation by storm water or have inadequate drainage should not be platted for any use as may increase danger to health life or property the subdivider may show by way of accurately engineered plans that a change to the topography in the proposed subdivision will eliminate flooding in the area in question and shall clearly demonstrate that any such planned topographical change will not unduly aggravate the flood hazard beyond the limits of the proposed subdivision if the city council determines that a flood problem does exist then it shall reject all or that part of the proposed subdivision lying within the floodplain any areas of land lying within a floodplain shall require specific compliance with act no 288 of the public acts of michigan mcl  et seq as amended and review by the land and water management division of the department of environmental quality art iii 8502 secs 8211582130  reserved article iv  improvements division 1  generally acceptable standards a distribution lines which serve areas outside the subdivided area and except for surface facilities related to underground service such as aboveground closure or terminals and such wires conduits or cables shall be placed within private easements provided to such service companies by the proprietor or within dedicated public ways provided that overhead local distribution lines within such residential area may be permitted upon written recommendation from the planning commission upon advisement from the planner or engineer and the approval of the council at the time of final plat approval where it is determined that overhead lines will not constitute a detriment to the health safety general welfare plat design and character of the subdivision all such facilities placed in dedicated public ways shall be planned so as not to conflict with other underground utilities all such facilities shall be constructed in accordance with standards of construction approved by the wires shall be placed in the street rightsofway b sewage disposal a sanitary sewer system including all appurtenances shall be required in all subdivisions which shall connect and outlet into a municipal sanitary sewer system 1 sanitary sewer specifications in addition to meeting all standards and specifications as published in the citys engineering manual the sanitary sewers must meet the following specifications a footing drains of any structure shall not be connected to the sanitary sewer b sewer profile the sewer profile shall indicate the length of run between each manhole the type of sewer pipe the size and slope of the sewer between manholes and any type of special bedding required top elevations of all manholes and inverts shall be indicated c water supply water mains fire hydrants and required water system appurtenances shall be constructed in such a manner as to adequately serve all lots shown on the subdivision plat both for domestic use and fire protection and shall be connected to a municipal water supply system 1 water mains in addition to meeting all standards and specifications as published in the citys engineering manual the water supply must meet the following specifications a laterals in general lateral water mains shall be eight inches in diameter sixinch diameter water mains shall not have a run longer than 400 feet between connections to an eightinch water main gate valves shall be located in the system such that not more than four valves need be turned off to isolate any section of water main moreover sufficient valves shall be placed such that not more than 30 lots shall be serviced within such section of water main which can be so isolated where possible gate valves shall be located at street intersections five feet from the intersecting street rightofway line b hydrants hydrants shall be installed along the water main at least every 500 feet in no case shall a house be more than 300 feet from a hydrant in commercial or industrial districts additional hydrants may be required hydrants shall be installed at the ends of all deadend water mains when near a street intersection hydrants shall be located 15 feet from the intersecting street rightofway hydrants shall be city standard location of hydrants shall be approved in writing by the fire chief c finished grades of hydrants and gate wells the plans shall indicate the finished grades of all hydrants and gate wells d storm drainage system an adequate storm drainage system including necessary storm sewers catch basins manholes bridges and other appurtenances shall be required in all subdivisions 1 county and state regulations the proprietor shall design and provide storm sewers and all drainage improvements and necessary drainage in accordance with the published rules and regulations of the macomb county drain commission pursuant to c of act no 288 of the public acts of michigan of 1967 mcl  et seq as amended 2 storm sewer specifications in addition to meeting all standards and specifications as published in the citys engineering manual storm sewers must meet the following specifications a collector sewers storm sewers installed for the purpose of providing drainage for streets shall be located in the street rightofway b submain sewers storm sewer submains installed for the purpose of connecting collector sewers with main line sewers or county drains shall be located in a public easement as determined by the engineer i field catch basins field catch basins shall be provided at all low points in the easement locate field catch basins such that not more than 300 feet of drainage runs into any catch basin from any one direction or a total of 600 feet of drainage from all directions ii improved open drains improved open drains may be permitted by the city engineer upon special circumstances in accordance with city engineering standards c rear yard drainage positive rear yard drainage shall be provided for each lot adequate provision shall be made for proper drainage of storm water runoff from each lot into a catch basis each yard shall be selfcontained to the extend that water does not run from one lot onto an adjacent lot but rather flows into the catch basin d storm sewer laterals lateral storm sewers not less than six inches in diameter shall be constructed from each rear yard catch basin to the street collector storm sewer the lateral shall also provide the outlet for the footing drain lead the lead shall be not less than fourinch diameter pipe for gravity sewer or not less than twoinch diameter pipe for sump pump discharge the lead shall be constructed at a minimum depth of three and onehalf feet on a minimum of one percent grade the materials and methods of construction shall be in accordance with the current city standards art iv 8502 grading and site drainage a soil erosion and sediment control principles in order to provide effective soil erosion and sediment control  practical combinations of the following technical principles shall be applied to the erosion control aspect of the grading plan 1 the smallest practical area of land shall be exposed at any one time during development 2 when land is exposed during development the exposure shall be kept to the shortest practical period of time and in no case shall exposure occur for longer than two months 3 temporary vegetation andor mulching shall be used to protect critical area exposed during development 4 sediment basins debris basins or silt traps shall be installed and maintained to remove sediment from runoff waters from land undergoing development 5 provisions shall be made to effectively accommodate the increased runoff caused by changed soil and surface conditions after development 6 the permanent final vegetation and structures shall be installed as soon as practical in the development 7 the development plan shall be fitted to the topography and soil so as to create the least erosion potential 8 wherever feasible natural vegetation shall be retained and protected b surface drainage standards 1 asphaltpaved or grasscovered areas shall have a minimum general slope of one percent with specific water carrying swales having a minimum slope of fourtenths of one percent 2 concrete paved surfaces shall have a minimum slope of fourtenths of one percent 3 all project areas shall drain stormwaters to suitable disposal structures which will prevent such storm water from flowing across adjacent private property and prevent damage to both private and public properties art iv 8502 sidewalks a hardship conditions for granting the council may authorize a variance from these regulations when in its opinion undue hardship may result from strict compliance in granting any variance the council shall prescribe only conditions that it deems necessary to or desirable for the public interest in making its findings as required in this section the council shall take into account the nature of the proposed use of land and the existing use of land in the vicinity the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed subdivision upon traffic conditions in the vicinity no variance shall be granted unless the council finds that 1 there are special circumstances or conditions affecting the property such that the strict application of the provisions of this chapter would deprive the applicant of the reasonable use of his land 2 the variance is necessary for the preservation and enjoyment of a substantial property right of the petitioner 3 the granting of the variance will not be detrimental to the public welfare or injurious to other property in the territory in which the property is situated art v 8502 division 2  complete neighborhood required elements of proposal the council may authorize a variance from these regulations in case of a plan for a complete community or neighborhood where such development is permitted by the zoning ordinance and which in the judgment of the council and after a recommendation is had from the commission provides adequate public spaces and includes provisions for efficient circulation light and air and other needs in making its findings as required in this section the council shall take into account the nature of the proposed use and the existing use of land in the vicinity the number of persons to reside or work in the proposed subdivision and the probable effect of the proposed development upon traffic conditions in the vicinity the council shall find that 1 there is adequate acreage and population in the proposed plan so as to support at least one elementary school 2 the standards and requirements of the zoning ordinance of the city are met 3 the planning commission has reviewed the plan and recommends its approval as having met the standards and intent of the master plan of land use as it relates to facility needs 4 in granting the variance it shall be valid only as long as the plan for the complete neighborhood is carried out as approved any departure from the plan shall immediately rescind any variance granted 5 the council shall establish a performance schedule to be met on the various aspects of the complete neighborhood plan art v 8502 application application for any such variance shall be submitted in writing by the proprietor at the time the stage 1 tentative preliminary plat is filed stating fully and clearly all facts relied upon by the proprietor and shall be supplemented with maps plans or other additional data which may aid in the analysis of the proposed project the plans for such developments shall include such covenants restrictions or other legal provisions necessary to guarantee the full achievement of the plan art v 8502 secs 8221382225  reserved articles viixiv  reserved secs 8222682440  reserved article xv  partition of lands restrictions no lot out lot or other parcel of land costs involving alcohol andor controlled substances footnotes  4  editors note adopted aug 21 199 did not specifically amend this   hence inclusion of  13 as a new art v  90919093 was at the discretion of the editor declaration of purpose the city finds that a significant number of the traffic arrests and traffic accidents in the city involve drivers operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance or a combination of both furthermore the city finds that there is a greater likelihood of personal injury or property damages in accidents involving a driver operating under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance or a combination of both as a result the city finds that a greater operational and financial burden has been placed on the citys public safety services by persons operating a motor vehicle under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance and that it is necessary to recover these increased emergency response costs  82195 definitions for the purpose of the terms listed below shall have the following meanings costs of an emergency response shall mean all direct and reasonable costs related to an emergency response incurred by the city or by a private individual or corporation operating at the request or direction of the city these costs shall include but are not limited to the costs of police firefighting emergency medical and rescue services  the salaries wages and fringe benefits of any personnel responding to the incident  the salaries wages and fringe benefits of any personnel engaged in investigating the incident and all costs of any related reports  all costs connected with the supervision personnel responding to or investigating any incident  all costs connected with the administration and processing of chemical tests of blood breath or urine of the driver  and all costs related to any prosecution of the person causing the incident emergency response shall mean providing sending or utilizing police firefighting emergency medical or rescue personnel by the city or by a private individual or corporation operating at the request or direction of the city in connection with any incident involving a driver of a motor vehicle operating under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance or a combination of intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance these incidents shall include but not be limited to any accident involving a motor vehicle where one or more of the drivers was operating the motor vehicle while under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance or a combination of intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance  and any traffic stop and arrest by a police officer when the driver was operating the motor vehicle while under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance or a combination of both  82195 liability for costs of an emergency response a person liable any person is liable for the costs of an emergency response if that person while under the influence of intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance or a combination of intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance proximately causes any incident resulting in an emergency response b presumptions for the purpose of a person is under the influence of an intoxicating liquor or a controlled substance or the combination of an intoxicating liquor and a controlled substance when his or her physical or mental abilities are impaired to a degree that he or she no longer has the ability to operate a motor vehicle with the caution characteristic of a sober person of ordinary prudence further it shall be presumed that a person was operating a motor vehicle while under the influence of an intoxicating liquor if a chemical analysis of his or her blood urine or breath indicates that the amount of alcohol in his or her blood was in excess of 007% c charge against person the costs of an emergency response shall be a charge against the person liable for the costs under the charge constitutes a debt of that person and is collectible by the city for incurring those costs in the same manner as in the case of an obligation under a contract expressed or implied d cost recovery schedule the city council shall from time to time adopt resolutions that set forth a schedule of the costs incurred in making an emergency response it shall be presumed that the costs listed in this schedule are the true costs incurred by the city and represent the costs of an emergency response this schedule shall be available to the public from either the city clerk or the police department e billing the chief of police or the chiefs agent may within 30 days of receiving a complete list of itemized costs of an emergency response submit a bill for these costs by first class mail or personal service to the person liable for the costs the bills shall require full payment in 30 days from the date of service f failure to pay  procedure to recover costs any failure by the person described in as liable for the costs of an emergency response to pay the bill within 30 days of service shall be considered a default in case of default the city may commence civil suit to recover the costs plus any additional costs or expenses allowed by law  82195 secs violation of these provisions  eff 5118  definitions decal means the sticker displayed on the front of every registered golf cart within the city which are obtained by completing and submitting the proper registration form to the richmond police department driver license means an operators or chauffeurs license or permit issued to an individual by the secretary of state under of the michigan vehicle pa 300 mcl  to mcl  as amended for that individual to operate a vehicle whether or not conditions are attached to the license or permit golf cart means a vehicle designed for transportation while playing the game of golf maintained portion means that portion of a road improved designated or ordinarily used for vehicular traffic operate means to ride in or on or be in actual physical control of the operation of the golf cart operator means a person who operates or is in actual physical control of the operation of a golf cart registration means the process every person intending to operate a motorized golf cart on roads or streets within the city must follow street means a road roadway street or rightofway within the city of richmond street system but does not include a private road the terms road roadway street and rightofway are interchangeable sunset and sunrise mean that time determined by the national weather service on any given day village means the city of richmond counties of macomb and st clair state of michigan  eff 5118  operation of golf carts on city streets a person may operate a golf cart on city streets subject to the following restrictions 1 a person shall not operate a golf cart on any street unless he or she is at least 16 years old and is licensed to operate a motor vehicle 2 the operator of a golf cart shall comply with the signal requirements of mcl  as amended that apply to the operation of a vehicle 3 all golf carts are required to have a red reflector on the rear of the golf cart that shall be visible from all distances up to 500 feet when in front of lawful low beams of headlamps on a motor vehicle 4 the operator of a golf cart shall obey by all sections pertaining to traffic in the michigan vehicle the uniform traffic 5 a person operating a golf cart upon a roadway shall ride as near to the right side of the roadway as practicable exercising due care when passing a standing vehicle or one proceeding in the same direction 6 a person shall not operate a golf cart on a state trunk line highway this subsection does not prohibit a person from crossing a state trunk line highway when operating a golf cart on a street of the city using the most direct line of crossing 7 where a usable and designated path for golf carts is provided adjacent to a road or street a person operating a golf cart shall be required to use that path a golf cart shall not be operated on a sidewalk constructed for the use of pedestrians 8 a person operating a golf cart shall not pass between lines of traffic but may pass on the left of traffic moving in his or her direction in the case of a twoway street or on the left or right of traffic in an unoccupied lane in the case of a oneway street 9 a golf cart shall be operated at a speed not to exceed 15 miles per hour and shall not be operated on a roadway or street with a speed limit of more than 30 miles per hour except to cross that roadway or street the city may designate roads or classifications of roads for use by golf carts {10 a golf cart shall not be operated on the streets of the city during the time period from onehalf hour before sunset to onehalf hour after sunrise 11 a person operating a golf cart or who is a passenger in a golf cart is not required to wear a crash helmet 12 a golf cart shall not be used to carry more persons at one time than the number for which it is designed and equipped 13 a golf cart operated on a street of the city is not required to be registered under this act for purposes of of the insurance  pa 218 mcl  as amended 14 a golf cart shall not be operated during weather events with snow andor ice on the ground 15 golf carts shall not be operated on a road or street in a negligent manner endangering any person or property or obstructing hindering or impeding the lawful course of travel of any motor vehicle or the lawful use by any pedestrian of public streets sidewalks paths trails walkways or parks 16 offroad vehicles such as gators allterrain vehicles atvs a multitrack or multiwheel drive vehicle dune buggy or likevehicles are not considered golf carts 17 this section does not apply to a police officer city officials employees contractors or volunteers in the performance of city duties  eff 5118  parking regulations the parking stopping and standing regulations provided in the city which may be adopted by reference therein shall also apply to golf carts operated in the city as if they are motor vehicles under those provisions  eff 5118  registration and decals a golf cart owners shall register each of policy selected by the applicant for coverage of personal injury or property damage resulting from operation of the subject golf cart the minimum amount of coverage shall be no less than $30000000 and the city of richmond shall be named as an additional insured the police department shall review and approve or deny each application and provide a list of registered golf carts to the city manager police on a clearly visible place on the front of the golf cart the decal shall be valid for one year c nonresidents may register their golf cart with the city as long as they have written approval from a richmond resident that the resident will act as the host property for the nonresidents golf cart the host resident will allow the golf cart trailer to be parked on their property so as not to take up parking public parking spaces d failure to register a golf cart or renew an existing registration shall constitute a violation of this article e the richmond police department retains the right to refuse to issue andor revoke any registration decal from any golf cart for any reason that is felt appropriate to ensure the safety and wellbeing of the citizens of city f any police officer may temporarily suspend any registration decal and ban further access on any public street or public property by any golf cart when in the opinion of that officer the golf cart is being used in a manner to cause damage to public property or members of the public g the city council reserves the right to waive the registration requirements of this ordinance for special events that utilize golf article ii  water supply and sewage disposal systems separation of systems the water supply and the sewage disposal systems of the city of richmond county of macomb state of michigan shall be independent systems to be designated as the water supply system and sewage disposal system each to be operated on a separate rate basis under the provisions of act 94 public acts of michigan 193 as amended i 7201 system components said water supply system and sewage disposal system shall include all water mains and laterals wells pumping stations sewer sewage disposal plant and all facilities or appurtenances used or useful in connection with the supplying and distributing of water or the collection treatment or disposal of sewage either now in existence or hereafter acquired said separate water supply and sewage disposal systems are sometimes herein referred to as the systems or system ii 7201 administration a the operation repair and management of the system and authorized improvements to the system shall be under the immediate supervision and control of the city manager subject however to supervision and control by the city council the city council may make such rules orders and regulations as it deems necessary to assure the efficient management and operation of the system b at any point in time when the city does not have a city manager in its employment and the city council has not appointed an acting city manager the city council shall be empowered to assume full responsibility and exercise complete authority as otherwise given to the city manager in administering and enforcing the provisions of this article c the city manager or his designee may regulate limit or prohibit the use of water for any purpose temporarily to cover special or emergency conditions such regulations shall restrict less essential water uses to the extent deemed necessary to assure an adequate supply for essential domestic commercial and industrial needs and for fire fighting d whenever city water shall be used for outdoor sprinkling contrary to any limitation or prohibition imposed such use shall be prima facie proof that it was so used or that such use was consented to approved or directed by the person or persons to whom such water was billed at the time of such use as appears from the records of the water department iii 7201 water rate a the rate to be charged for water services furnished to the incity consumers of the city of richmond shall be the sum of the water commodity charge and the water readinesstoserve charge until otherwise provided by ordinance of the governing body the water commodity charge shall be a rate established by resolution of the governing body per 1000 gallons for each quarterly threemonth period the water readinesstoserve charge shall be a rate established by resolution of the governing body for every dwelling apartment unit mobile home or other residential unit furnished city water and the nonresidential commercial and industrial water readinesstoserve charge for every building or structure furnished city water shall be a separate rate established by resolution of the governing body the readinesstoserve charge for water service shall not be imposed upon any premises where water service was not provided at any time during the quarterly billing period b charges for water service to consumers outside the corporate limits of the city of richmond shall be the sum of the water commodity charge the water readinesstoserve charge the water quarterly debt service charge and the water return on investment charge the water quarterly debt service charge and the water return on investment charge shall be as prescribed by resolution of the governing body c water to be furnished by the system shall be measured by the meter installed and controlled by the city and no new or additional nonmeter services shall be provided by the city for any premises previously provided water service otherwise than the water rate shall be reasonable and shall be established by resolution by the governing body the nonmeter water rate for outofcity water service shall be the sum of the nonmeter water rate for outofcity consumers as established by resolution the water quarterly debt service and the water return on investment iva 7201 sewage treatment rate a the rate to be charged for sewage treatment services furnished by the system for incity service shall be the sum of the sewer commodity charge and the sewer readinesstoserve charge the sewer commodity charge shall be a rate as prescribed by resolution of the governing body per 1000 gallons for each quarter threemonth period the residential sewer readinesstoserve charge for each quarterly threemonth period or fraction thereof shall be a rate as prescribed by resolution of the governing board for every dwelling apartment units mobile home or other residential unit  and the nonresidential commercial and industrial sewer readinesstoserve charge for every building or structure shall be a rate with an additional surcharge for high strength wastewater both as prescribed by resolution of the governing body the readinesstoserve charge for sewage treatment service shall not be imposed on any premises where service was not provided at any time during the quarterly billing b outofcity sewer rates shall be the sum of the incity rate as noted above the sewer quarterly debt service charge and the sewer return on investment charge unless modified by a separate agreement with the city the sewer debt service charge and sewer return on investment service charge shall be as prescribed by resolution of the governing body c for any premises that is being provided water service other than the rate to be thereof both as prescribed by resolution of the governing body ivb 7201 billings and billing disputes charges for water consumed as well as sewage disposal services rendered shall be assessed and collected in four quarterly periods or more often if circumstances require such billings shall be due and payable on the date specified on the invoice amounts owed shall be paid on or before said date and if not shall be declared delinquent whereupon a penalty of ten percent of the full amount of the billing shall be added thereto and collected in addition to the amount billed the city manager is authorized to approve reasonable payment arrangements for customers with delinquent utility accounts if a utility customer disputes a billing and it is determined by administration that the meter reading used to calculate the billing matches the reading on the meter at the customers request the meter may be removed and tested for measurement accuracy in accordance with proper procedures established by city administration if the result of such meter test shows that the meter was reading accurately or was underreading actual usage no adjustment to the utility billing shall be made however if such meter test shows that the meter was overreading actual usage city administration shall determine the amount to be billed to the customer for the disputed billing period based upon the customers usage records the city council shall establish by resolution the fee for removing and replacing disputed water meters except that a customer shall not be charged for such meter removal and replacement if it is determined that the utility billing dispute was the result of a meter overreading actual usage in such cases where it is determined by city administration that a utility customers billing dispute is the result of a water leak which is the responsibility of the customer and which did not result in water discharging to the sanitary sewer system city administration may provide an adjustment to the sanitary sewer portion of the billing based upon the customers usage records the city manager is authorized to approve reasonable payment arrangements for a customer who because of water leaks or other unusual circumstances beyond the control of the customer resulting in a substantial increase in the amount of the subject quarterly utility billing claims financial difficulty in paying such billing ivc 7201   7703 water meters a water meters and remote meter readers shall be furnished by the city at a charge as prescribed by resolution of the governing body at the expense of device shall be installed maintained and kept in good repair by the owner of the private distribution system and at the owners expense d all water metering devices shall remain the property of the established for the purpose of charging each and every new water user his or her fair share of the cost of such integral elements of the water system as wells pumps and appurtenances pump houses oversized mains storage tanks and distribution lines connecting the wells and storage tanks within the overall water system sewage disposal system capital charges shall be established for the purpose of charging each and every new user of the sewage treatment plant lift stations and the portion of the transmission network which is essential to the overall sewage disposal system but of general rather than specific benefit to users of the system b all nonresidential uses and all multifamily residential uses multifamily including mobile home parks but excluding duplexes triplexes and quadplexes shall submit to the city manager prior to connecting to the city water supply system or sewage disposal system a computation prepared by a michigan licensed professional engineer indicating the service line sizing and water main capacity required for the proposed use of the premises to be connected provided that in no instance shall said computation be binding upon the city if the city manager andor city engineer determine it to indicate an improper line sizing andor meter capacity c fees for capital charges shall be paid in cash prior to connection to the city water supply system or sewer system unless the city council upon recommendation of the city manager determined that the total payment in cash prior to connection constitutes an unreasonable hardship and further that the best interests of the city would be served by allowing for payment of the capital charge in installments  provided that in no case shall installment payments extend for a period of time in excess of five years that installment payments be made in equal amounts including a finance charge within plus or minus one percent of the current prime rate of interest that no less than onefifth of the total capital charge be paid in cash prior to connection and that the terms of any arrangement for installment payments be set out in a contract acceptable to the city council and the party proposing to connect to the city water supply system or sewer system d capital charges for outofcity users proposing to connect to the city water supply system or sewage disposal system shall be one and onehalf times the fee for incity users ivg 7201 main extensions a all extensions of water mains and sanitary sewer mains from the city systems existing as of the effective date of this article shall have prior approval of the city manager and city council and shall be made at the expense of the developer or benefiting property owners to be served by the main all water mains and sanitary sewer mains shall be constructed in accordance with the latest edition of the ten state standards the city of richmond engineering standards and the citys water system or sanitary sewer system master plan b for those areas not covered by the water andor sewer system master plan the city may participate in part or all of the costs of extending mains including oversize mains for the purpose of system wide improvement or expansion or for general benefit rather than for special benefit the total cost of extending mains eight inches or smaller in diameter shall be borne by the developer or the benefiting property owners unless the city council shall upon recommendation of the city manager determine the extension to be partially or wholly for overall system improvement or for some other specific reason determines that the total cost cannot fairly be charged on the basis of special benefit accruing to abutting property in the case of platted subdivisions the developer shall pay the cost of main extension and shall reimburse the city for its actual costs incurred in making or causing to be made inspections thereof and in the case of unplatted lands main extensions shall be financed by special assessment against the benefited property provided that the assessment shall not exceed the actual cost of the extension plus engineering and administrative costs and further provided that a corner lot shall be assessed only its fair share of the cost of extending the main that actually serves or is intended to serve it  corner lots shall participate only in the cost of the main installed along one side of the lot not in the cost of the main which may be installed along a side of the lot but which is not intended to serve that lot the cost for this latter main shall be divided proportionately among the benefiting properties which it is intended to serve c for any main extension made to serve any lot or parcel which is separated from the existing system by vacant property the developer or owner shall enter into a water or sewer main extension contract with the city and shall pay the entire cost of the original construction of the main extension vacant land as the property abutting such water main is developed and connections are made to it the city may collect but has no obligation to collect a charge per front foot based upon the original construction cost and if so collected shall reimburse the developer to the extent of the collection so made less ten percent for administrative expense provided that the developers right to reimbursement under a water or sewer main extension contract shall in no event exceed a period of five years from the date of the execution of said contract and all payments shall cease at that time regardless of the amount that has at that time been received by the developer in no instance shall the actual amount paid to the developer by the city exceed the original cost of the extension d all water and sewer mains or extensions thereof shall be installed only in dedicated public streets alleys or rightsofway or in easements which grant the city rights at least equal to the right it would enjoy in dedicated streets alleys or rightsofway and shall become the property of the city at the time of connection to the city system e plans for main extensions must be prepared by a michigan licensed professional engineer and submitted to the city manager or the city engineer for review and approval prior to commencement of construction thereof f before main trenches are backfilled the developer or contractor must call the city and request an inspection of the main installation and in no case will water or sewer service be rendered main which has not been inspected and approved by the city and which has not been properly tested and found to be in compliance with standards established by the michigan department of environmental quality ivh 7201 sewer and water permit and inspection fees there shall be separate of the person ivk 7201 cross connections a a cross connection shall not be made between the public water supply system and a secondary water supply a cross connection shall not be made by submerged inlet a cross connection shall not be made between the public water supply and piping which may contain sanitary waste or a chemical contaminant a cross connection shall not be made between the public water supply and piping immersed in a tank or vessel which may contain a contaminant b the city of richmond adopts by reference the water supply cross connection rules of the michigan department of environmental quality being r  to r  of the michigan administrative complete copy of this code is available for public use and inspection at the office of the city clerk 68225 main street richmond michigan c it shall be the duty of the city to cause inspections to be made of all properties served by the public water supply where cross connections with the public water supply is deemed possible the frequency of inspections and reinspections based on potential health hazards involved shall be as established by the city council and as approved by the michigan department of environmental quality d the representative of the city shall have the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection to the public water supply system of the city for the purpose of inspecting the piping system or systems thereof for cross connections on request the owner lessees or occupants of any property so served shall furnish to the inspection agency any pertinent information regarding the piping system or systems on such property the refusal of such information or refusal of access when requested shall be deemed prima facie evidence of the presence of cross connections e the potable water supply made available on the properties served by the public water supply shall be protected from possible contamination as specified by this article and by the state plumbing code any water outlet which could be used for potable or domestic purposes and which is not supplied by the potable system must be labeled in a conspicuous manner as water unsafe for drinking f the provisions of this section do not supersede the state plumbing code but are supplementary to it v 7201 enforcement a in addition to other remedies available for collection charges for service provided by the system shall constitute a lien on the property served and if not paid within six months after the same are due the official or officials in charge of the collection thereof shall prior to april 1st of each year certify to the city assessing officer the fact of such delinquency whereupon the city assessing officer shall enter such delinquent charges upon the next general city tax roll as a charge against such premises and the same shall be collected and the lien thereof enforced in the same manner as general city taxed against such premises are collected and the lien thereof enforced b at the citys discretion it may hold the owner the tenant or both responsible for charges for water and sewer services to rental or leased property the city shall have a lien against such property in the same manner as described above unless the owner or landlord has complied with both section 5 of act no 178 of the public acts of 1939 as amended and section 21 of act no 94 of the public acts of 1933 as amended respectively being mcl  and mcl  where notice is given by an owner or landlord that a tenant is responsible for such charges as provided in section 21 of act no 94 of water and sewage disposal charges within 30 days from due date for any premises for which water is shut off such water shall not be turned on until a turn on charge as prescribed by resolution of the governing body is paid d in addition to any other remedies available for enforcement of this article the city shall have the right to shut off water to any premises for any violation of this article or any written order of the city pursuant thereto for any premises for which the water is shut off such water shall not be turned on until the violation has been rectified and a turn on charge as prescribed by resolution of the governing body is paid e concerning cross connections in addition to any other remedies available under this article the city may take any precautionary measure which the introduction of pollutants into the wastewater system which will interfere with the normal operation of the system or contaminate the resulting municipal sludge  b to prevent the introduction of pollutants into the wastewater system which do not receive adequate treatment in the potw and which will pass system into receiving waters or the atmosphere or otherwise be incompatible with the system  c to improve the opportunity to recycle and reclaim wastewater and sludge from the system d to provide for equitable distribution of the cost of municipal wastewater system i 101501 definitions unless the context specifically indicates otherwise the following terms and phrases as used in this article shall have the meanings hereinafter designated act or the act shall mean the federal water pollution control act also known as the clean water act as amended 33 usc 125 et seq applicable county health department shall mean the macomb county health department authorized representative of industrial user an authorized representative of an industrial user may be a a principal executive officer of at least the level of vice president if the industrial user is a corporation  b a general partner or proprietor if the industrial user is a partnership or proprietorship respectively  or c a duly authorized representative of the individual designated above if such representative is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the indirect discharge originates or for environmental matters of the company authorization for this representative must be submitted in writing to the city by the individual designated in a and b hereof biochemical oxygen demand bod the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedure five days at 20 centigrade expressed in terms of weight and concentration milligrams per liter building drain shall mean that part of the lowest horizontal piping of a drainage system which receives discharge from drainage pipes inside the walls of the building and conveys it to the building sewer beginning five feet outside the inner face of the building wall building sewer shall mean the extension from the building drain to the public sewer or other place of disposal bypass the intentional diversion of waste streams from any portion of a users pretreatment facility categorical standards national categorical pretreatment standards or pretreatment standard chemical oxygen demand cod a measure of the oxygenconsuming capacity of inorganic and organic matter present in water or wastewater it is expressed as the amount of oxygen consumed from a chemical oxidant in a specified test it does not differentiate between stable and unstable organic matter and thus does not necessarily correlate with biochemical oxygen demand also known as oc and doc oxygen consumed and dichromate oxygen consumed respectively chlorine demand shall mean the difference between the amount of chlorine applied and the amount of free chlorine available at the end of the contact time expressed in milligrams per liter city the city of richmond michigan its agents and employees city manager shall mean the manager of the citys administration and utilities or his authorized representative combined sewer shall mean a sewer receiving both surface runoff and sewage commercial waste shall mean a liquid or watercarried waste material from a commercial business engaged in buying selling exchanging goods or engaging in said goods or services compatible pollutant a substance amenable to treatment in the wastewater treatment plant such as biochemical oxygen demand suspended solids ph and fecal coliform bacteria plus additional pollutants identified in the npdes permit if the publiclyowned treatment works was designed to treat such pollutants and in fact does remove such pollutant to a substantial degree examples of such additional pollutants may include chemical oxygen demand total organic carbon phosphorus and phosphorus compounds nitrogen compounds fats oils and greases of animal or vegetable origin composite sample a series of samples taken over a specific time period whose volume is proportional to the flow in the waste stream which are combined into one sample cooling water the water discharged from any use such as air conditioning cooling or refrigeration or to which the only pollutant added is heat debt service charge means charges levied to customers of the wastewater system which are used to pay principal interest and administrative costs of retiring the debt incurred for construction of the wastewater system the debt service charge shall be in addition to the user charge specified below direct discharge the discharge of treated or untreated wastewater directly to the waters of the state environmental protection agency or epa the us environmental protection agency administrator or other duly authorized official garbage shall mean solid wastes from the preparation cooking and dispensing of food and from the handling storage and sale of produce grab sample a sample which is taken from a waste stream on a onetime basis with no regard to the flow in the waste stream and without consideration of time holding tank waste any waste from holding tanks such as vessels chemical toilets campers trailers septic tanks and vacuumpump tank trucks incompatible pollutants any pollutant which is not a compatible pollutant indirect discharge the discharge or the introduction of nondomestic pollutants into the potw including holding tank waste discharged into the system industrial wastes the wastewater discharges from industrial manufacturing trade or business processes or wastewater discharge from any structure with these characteristics as distinct from their employees domestic wastes or wastes from sanitary conveniences infiltration shall mean any waters entering the system from the ground means as but not limited to defective pipes pipe joints connections or manhole walls infiltration does not include and is distinguished from inflow infiltrationinflow shall mean the total quantity of water from both infiltration and inflow inflow shall mean any waters entering the system sources as but not limited to building downspouts footing or yard drains cooling water discharges seepage lines from springs and swampy areas and storm drain cross connections interference the inhibition or disruption of the potw treatment processes or operations which contributes to a violation of any requirement of the citys npdes permit or reduces the efficiency of the potw the term also includes prevention of sewage sludge use or disposal by the potw laboratory determination the measurements tests and analyses of the characteristics of waters and wastes in accordance with the methods contained in the latest edition at the time of any such measurement test or analysis of
